LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  The Socialist Republic of Viet Nam  
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention

Project Description  The  Project  is  designed  to  provide  (i)  a  244-kilometer  grade-
separated  and  access-controlled  highway,  including 
10 interchanges with toll booths and five service areas, starting at 
Noi Bai in a suburb of Hanoi and ending at Lao Cai, on the border 
with the People’s Republic of China (PRC) in northwest Viet Nam; 
(ii) electric, communications, and tolling systems and associated 
facilities,  and  the  Vietnam  Expressway  Corporation’s  (VEC’s) 
highway  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  equipment  and 
vehicles; and (iii) capacity building for VEC on management of 
project implementation, corporate financing management, O&M of 
highways, and safeguard planning and implementation. 
   
Rationale  The Noi Bai–Lao Cai Highway is an integral section of the eastern 
link of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Northern Economic 
Corridor, connecting Kunming in Yunnan province of the PRC with 
Hanoi, and Hai Phong and Cai Lan ports in Viet Nam. Most of the 
existing national road between Hanoi and Lao Cai is narrow, with 
a  large  number  of  bridges  with  limited  capacity,  and  there  is 
substantial  ribbon  development  on  most  of  its  length.  By 
upgrading the Noi Bai–Lao Cai section, the Kunming–Hai Phong 
Transport Corridor will be completed.  
 
Poverty  in  the  project  area  is  largely  a  result  of  inadequate 
access, caused by poor local road infrastructure. People living 
below  the  poverty  line  are  suffering  from  poor  accessibility  to 
economic  opportunities,  education,  and  health  services.  The 
highway will decrease the cost of travel, which will encourage 
economic  activities  in  the  project  area,  provide  employment 
opportunities  for  the  local  population,  and  improve  access  to 
social services. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The Project will: (i) construct an efficient, safe, and reliable high-
standard road from Noi Bai to Lao Cai; (ii) create a new freight 
transport link between PRC’s Yunnan province, Hanoi, and Hai

ii   
Phong and Cai Lan ports in northern Viet Nam; (iii) enable 1-day 
transport between Kunming, Hanoi, and Hai Phong; (iv) stimulate 
operations of long-distance bus transportation services and local 
public transportation; (v) generate revenue for VEC through the 
highway  toll;  and  (vi)  create  business  opportunities  and 
employment for local people along the highway. The Project will 
have the following impacts: (i) sustainable economic growth and 
poverty reduction in the project area and along the Kunming–Hai 
Phong  transport  corridor,  (ii) strengthened  connections  with 
Yunnan province and strengthened international competitiveness; 
and (iii) enhancing mobility of people living along the highway.

Implementation  VEC will have overall responsibility for project implementation. 
Arrangements  VEC  will  establish  a  project  management  team  to  manage 
implementation of the Project. The project management team will 
have responsibility for day-to-day project implementation, and will 
coordinate with the people’s committees of provinces affected by 
the project—Hanoi city, and Vinh Phuc, Pho Tho, Yen Bai, and 
Lao  Cai  provinces—in  implementing  the  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement  activities  and  livelihood  development  and  income 
restoration programs. 
   
Procurement  Civil works and equipment to be financed under the loans will be 
procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time). 
   
Consulting Services  The project supervision consulting services will be implemented 
by  an  international  consulting  firm  in  association  with  national 
consultants. Consulting inputs will be about 510 person-months of 
international consulting services and about 6,200 person-months 
of  national  consulting  services  for  (i)  construction  supervision; 
(ii) assistance  to  VEC  in  social  development  activities  and  in 
environmental  management,  land  acquisition,  and  resettlement 
activities; (iii) project performance monitoring; (iv) assistance to 
VEC  in  procuring  equipment  for  the  highway  O&M;  and  (v) 
capacity  building  of  VEC  staff  on  project  implementation, 
environmental  management,  land  acquisition  and  resettlement, 
social development assistance, corporate financing management, 
and O&M of the highway. The duration of the consulting services 
will be about 46 months. The international consulting firm will be 
recruited using the quality- and cost-based selection (QCBS) and 
full technical proposal procedure in accordance with Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The 
quality–cost ratio for QCBS is 80:20. 
   
Project Benefits and  The Project will (i) reduce travel time between Noi Bai and Lao 
Beneficiaries  Cai from 7–10 hours to 3–4 hours, (ii) reduce the volume of traffic 
passing through cities and towns in the project area, (iii) reduce 
the transport distance for container and other freight, (iv) allow 
operations  of  frequent  long-distance  bus  services  along  the 
highway and feeder public transportation services connecting the 
highway bus stops to communes, (v) reduce the number of traffic 
accidents, (vi) generate toll revenue to cover debt service of VEC, 
and  (vii)  create  small  and  medium  businesses  and  generate 
employment opportunities for local people.  
 
The  Project’s  economic  internal  rate  of  return  is  estimated  at 
18.2%. The Project’s financial internal rate of return after tax is 
estimated at 6.5%, which exceeds the weighted average cost of 
capital of 2.6%.

iv   
The major project beneficiaries will be (i) highway users, including 
cargo forwarders, bus operators, and tourists; (ii) local residents, 
who  will  benefit  from  improved  mobility  and  lower  prices  of 
commodities and transport services; (iii) local laborers involved in 
the  construction  works  and  supply  of  materials  during  project 
implementation and later in operation of the highway; (vi) local 
and international manufacturers and traders, who will be able to 
establish new businesses and increase production capacity, (v) 
VEC, who will receive toll revenue from highway users; (vi) bus 
operators, who will be able to expand their businesses; and (vii) 
port authorities in north Viet Nam, who will benefit from increased 
cargo volume. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  VEC’s human resources and organizational structure are currently 
inadequate  to  implement  a  large-scale  highway  construction 
project. The lack of knowledge of and experience with safeguards, 
corporate finance, and highway O&M are of particular concern. 
The project supervision consultant will provide on-the-job training 
to VEC staff.  
 
One concern is potential project implementation delays caused by 
delayed land acquisition and resettlement, delayed procurement, 
and/or  poor  performance  of  the  contractors.  To  avoid  project 
implementation  delays,  the  Project  will  take  the  following 
approaches: (i) notice to commence civil works on a particular 
section will be issued only when land acquisition and resettlement 
have been satisfactorily completed; (ii) VEC will proceed with the 
initial steps of procurement of the civil works before signing the 
Loan and Project Agreements; and (iii) prequalification of bidders 
will be undertaken to eliminate bidders that lack the technical and 
financial capacity to implement highway construction contracts of 
this size and complexity.   
 
The  highway’s  construction  will  involve  a  large  amount  of 
embankment  construction  and  excavation,  acquisition  of 
residential  and  agricultural  lands,  and  resettlement  of  project-
affected people, although the final alignment has been developed 
to ensure that environmentally sensitive areas are avoided and 
involuntary resettlement is kept to a minimum. An environmental 
impact assessment was undertaken, and a full resettlement plan, 
including an ethnic minority development plan, was prepared to 
mitigate these risks. 
 
The Project will increase road traffic and mobility of goods and 
people, and consequently could increase HIV incidence, illicit drug 
use, and human trafficking in local communities. The Project will 
include a technical assistance component to minimize these risks. 
Accidents  between  highway  users  and  the  local  people  may 
occur, in particular in the early period of highway operation, since 
there  is  limited  experience  in  Viet  Nam  with  access-controlled 
roads. The project supervision consultants will develop a road

safety campaign focusing on the access-controlled highway. 
 
The economic and financial viability of the Project depends on 
traffic demand on the highway. Moreover, traffic demand will be 
affected  by  toll  levels.  VEC  has  agreed  to  set  toll  levels  that 
optimize highway accessibility while ensuring that the Project is 
economically  and  financially  viable,  and  that  VEC  remains 
financially viable and sustainable. 
   
Technical Assistance  ADB is financing the ongoing TA 6321-REG: Fighting HIV/AIDS in 
Asia  and  the  Pacific  (financed  by  the  Cooperation  Fund  for 
Fighting  HIV/AIDS  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific),  which  provides  a

human trafficking prevention program to minimize exposure of the 
local population to these risks through additional allocation of the 
cooperation fund.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS): Kunming–Hai 
Phong Transport Corridor—Noi Bai–Lao Cai Highway Project.  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  The  Kunming–Hai  Phong  Transport  Corridor  consists  of  multiple  transport  modes, 
namely road, rail, and inland waterway. To meet the growing transport demand in the project 
area, possible alternatives to transport infrastructure projects were considered. The alternatives 
were reviewed based on travel time, alignments, technical designs, social and environmental 
impacts, and economic and financial viability. The analysis concluded that constructing the 
proposed Noi Bai–Lao Cai Highway, and rehabilitating and upgrading the existing railway—for 
which ADB approved a loan in 20061—are important for the corridor development.2 While the 
(cid:31)F
railway project is expected to partly meet the increasing transport demand, it will not completely 
satisfy the demand for all the various kinds of traffic—particularly passenger traffic and high-
value general cargo traffic, which require a more flexible and responsive mode to meet the 
needs of a market economy. The Project was proposed to satisfy these needs. 
 
3.  The Noi Bai–Lao Cai Highway is an integral section of the eastern link of the GMS 
Northern Economic Corridor, connecting Kunming in Yunnan province of the People’s Republic 
of China (PRC) with Hanoi and Hai Phong in Viet Nam. In Yunnan province, a 400-kilometer 
(km) expressway with four to six lanes from Kunming to the border with Viet Nam will be 
completed in 2008. However, in Viet Nam, most of the existing national road between Hanoi and 
Lao Cai, on the border with the PRC, is narrow, contains a large number of limited-capacity 
bridges, and has substantial ribbon development on most sections. These factors severely limit 
its capacity and reduce the possibility of improving it to cater for the projected substantial growth 
in traffic demand in the corridor. The section of the highway from Noi Bai to Hanoi and Hai 
Phong has been improved with assistance from other external donor agencies. Only the Noi 
Bai–Lao Cai section needs to be upgraded to complete the Kunming–Hai Phong Highway. The 
project feasibility study confirmed the necessity and viability of a modern highway linking the 
existing highway network around Hanoi, at Noi Bai, with the border crossing at Lao Cai.3 The 
(cid:31)F
design and monitoring framework for the Project is in Appendix 1. 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
4.  The proposed highway will originate in Hanoi, and cross Vinh Phuc, Pho Tho, Yen Bai, 
and Lao Cai provinces. Together, these provinces have a population of about 7 million—8.4% of 
the total population of Viet Nam—and were responsible for 11.4% of gross domestic product 
(GDP). Viet Nam is one of the fastest growing economies in Asia, recording an average annual 
growth in GDP of 7.5% over the last decade. Per capita GDP in the country was $622 in 2005. 
Per capita GDP in 2005 was $1,381 in Hanoi; but only $503 in Vinh Phuc, $327 in Pho Tho, 
$266 in Yen Bai, and $313 in Lao Cai provinces, which were all below the country per capita

in Yen Bai, and $198 in Lao Cai provinces. It is noted that the economy of Hanoi, and Vinh Phuc

2 years. The highway will be used as a transport link connecting two economically developing 
areas, and also contribute to economic growth in provinces sandwiched between areas that are 
rapidly growing economically. 
 
5.  In the context of the GMS and regional integration, economic cooperation between 
Viet Nam and PRC has increased since the late 1990s. PRC is Viet Nam’s third largest export 
market, and largest import supplier. In 2005 the value of exports to PRC was $2.3 billion and the 
value of imports was $6.2 billion.4 Yunnan province is a major producer of tobacco, minerals, 
(cid:31)F
steel, and fertilizer. Viet Nam, on the other hand, produces vegetables, fruits, seafood, crude oil, 
rubber, minerals, and light industrial goods such as textiles and footwear. So Yunnan province 
and Viet Nam have become important trade partners. Cross-border trade between Yunnan 
province and Viet Nam grew from $351 million in 2004 to $477 million in 2006, a year-on-year 
increase of around 15%. Around 1 million tons of cargo is transported annually across the 
Hekou–Lao Cai border crossing points. There is a roughly equal split between goods carried by 
road and by rail. Arrangements for initial implementation of the GMS Cross-Border Transport 
Agreement  at  the  Hekou–Lao  Cai  border  crossing  points  have  been  finalized.  In  addition, 
agreement has been reached by the two governments to consider, at the earliest possible time, 
expanding the scope of the existing bilateral road transport agreement to include the entire 
Kunming–Hanoi–Hai Phong transport corridor as an interim measure until the relevant annexes 
and protocols of the GMS Cross-Border Transport Agreement have been ratified. This will 
facilitate the exchange of commercial traffic rights along the corridor, which would reduce the 
incidence of costly and time-consuming transshipment at the Hekou–Lao Cai border crossing 
points. 
 
6.  The passage of containerized freight is particularly important for the trading relationship. 
Forwarders of overseas container cargo in Kunming do not currently use the Kunming–Hekou–
Lao Cai–Hanoi–Hai Phong route, partly because of the poor condition of the Lao Cai–Hanoi 
section in Viet Nam, inefficient custom control procedures at the Hekou–Lao Cai border, and the 
high  cost  of  transshipping  containers  at the border  crossing.  Instead,  they  send  container 
cargos by rail or road to the large ports in Guangzhou province (PRC), which takes up to 
6 days, and by road to the nearest ports in Guangxi province (PRC), which is about 1,050 km 
from Kunming. The proposed Noi Bai–Lao Cai Highway will allow forwarders in Kunming to 
reach Hai Phong and Cai Lan ports, which contain large container facilities, in 1 day. Once the 
proposed  Noi  Bai–Lao  Cai  Highway  has  been  completed,  and  the  ADB-supported  border 
crossing operation is streamlined, a substantial number of containers originating in Kunming 
could be diverted to the Kunming–Hai Phong route. Viet Nam would benefit from this through 
transit and port fees, among other benefits. 
 
7.  The major sources of livelihood in the project area are related to agriculture. Rice is the 
major crop in the project area. In the lowland areas where the proposed highway will be 
constructed, crops for household consumption are also cultivated, and the livelihood system 
includes rearing of livestock—primarily pigs and to a lesser extent poultry and cattle. Upland 
agriculture is typically the domain of ethnic minorities in the project area, but is only significant in 
Yen Bai and Lao Cai and to a much lesser extent in Vinh Phuc and Phu Tho. There are 
sophisticated and highly effective terraced rice production systems in the higher mountainous 
areas of Lao Cai. In recent times, cash crops such as cinnamon and cassava have been

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
8.  Viet Nam’s economy has grown at 7–8% per annum over the past decade, and the 
Government estimates that this growth will continue, as reflected in the forthcoming Five-Year 
Socio-Economic Development Plan 2006–2010.5 While this growth has had a dramatic impact 
(cid:31)F
on the country’s poverty rate, which declined from about 58% in 1993 to an estimated 20% in 
2006, it has severely strained the capacity of basic economic infrastructure, particularly power 
and transportation systems. The feasibility study of the Project has found that traffic is growing 
at about twice the rate of GDP and that this high growth rate is likely to continue beyond 2020, 
reflecting Viet Nam’s low level of vehicle ownership.6 Appendix 2 provides an analysis of the 
(cid:31)F
road subsector. 
 
  1.  The Government’s Strategy 
 
9.  The Government is acutely aware of the negative impact of inadequate infrastructure on 
growth  and  poverty  reduction.  It  is  beginning  to  see  the  adverse  impact  of  infrastructure 
bottlenecks on foreign investment, and on its desire to spread development more equitably to 
areas far from the major urban centers (Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City, Da Nang, etc.). For the critical 
transport infrastructure, the Government is taking a dual approach to developing the country’s 
road capacity: (i) developing a network of high-capacity expressways and highways linking the 
main  urban  areas  with  (a)  each  other,  (b)  less-developed  regions  of  the  country  and,  (c) 
neighboring countries; and (ii) developing the institutions required to plan, design, implement, 
and manage this network.  
 
10.  The existing national road system was mainly constructed with two traffic lanes, although 
there are short lengths with four lanes. Traffic management is rudimentary and the rate of traffic 
accidents is very high (Appendix 2). Government studies have indicated that the main national 
highway  network  should  be  widened,  and  an  expressway  and  modern  highway  network 
throughout Viet Nam should be built to connect important economic zones, large urban centers 
and  industrial  zones,  and  international  borders.  Reflecting  this  need,  the  Government  has 
directed the Ministry of Transport (MOT) to prepare an expressway master plan. ADB has 
provided technical assistance (TA) to assist MOT with completing the plan, of which of the 
proposed highway is an integral part.7

create  an  institutional  and  financial  framework  conducive  to  accelerating  infrastructure 
development. MOT is being restructured to differentiate between regulation and infrastructure 
development and operations. Four modal administrations in road, railway, inland waterway, and 
maritime have been created under MOT. In the road subsector, the aim of the restructuring is to

  2.  Lessons Learned 
 
12.  Viet  Nam  country  portfolio  review  missions  have  noted  that  there  have  been 
implementation delays in previous road projects, in particular during the project start-up phase. 
Past project designs have required that project supervision consultants prepare detailed designs 
and bidding documents for civil works, meaning that the initial 1–3 years of the loan period were

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
18.  The current travel time between Kunming and Hai Phong is more than 2 days. This will

B.  Outputs 
 
22.  The  highway  will  have  a  high  design  speed,  be  fully  grade-separated  and  access-

C.  Special Features 
26.  Subregional Highway Network Development. Entry of PRC traffic into Viet Nam is 
limited to the Lao Cai border area at present. Likewise, entry of Vietnamese traffic into the PRC 
is limited to the Hekou border area. Freight is transshipped by workers from truck to truck at the 
border areas. This results in high transportation costs and longer haulage times. The GMS 
transport corridor concept, of which the highway is an integral section, will enhance social and 
economic activities by removing border-crossing barriers. The governments of Viet Nam and 
PRC agreed to implement the GMS Cross-Border Transport Agreement for the Lao Cai–Hekou 
border, which streamlines cross-border operations and grants transit traffic rights for traffic 
transiting to or from the territory of other signatories of the Agreement. Travel time on the 
current Kunming–Hai Phong route currently averages about 2 days for passenger cars and 3 
days for trucks. The proposed highway will reduce travel times between Hanoi and Lao Cai from 
7 hours to 3 hours for passenger cars, and from 10 hours to 4 hours for trucks. Taking into 
consideration  expressway  construction  in  Yunnan  Province,  and  the  streamlining  of  cross-
border operations, travel from Kunming to Hai Phong will be reduced to about 1 day once the 
project highway is completed. This decrease in travel time and cost could induce international 
freight originating in Kunming to shift from PRC ports to Viet Nam ports via the Kunming–Hai 
Phong  Transport  Corridor,  and  consequently  encourage  economic  activities  in  the  project 
provinces. 
 
27.  ADF  Financing. The Project’s financing plan includes a substantial portion of ADF 
support. This reflects two specific project characteristics: (i) the project highway, particularly the 
section from Yen Bai to Lao Cai, passes through areas with high levels of poverty; and (ii) the 
Project has a strong subregional focus (reflecting this, the ADF allocation is sourced in part from 
ADB’s ADF IX subregional allocation). From a poverty perspective, the northwest area of Viet 
Nam is the country’s poorest. In 2004, the portion of the area’s population living below the 
poverty line was about 52%, compared with a countrywide average of 23%. Much of this

9 
difference reflects the lack of access of the western portion of the project area to major areas of 
economic activity, employment opportunities, etc, which the project highway will substantially 
improve. From a subregional perspective, the ADF allocation supports the connection of two 
economically dominant areas—Hanoi–Hai Phong and Kunming—through a hinterland that is 
much less developed. The specific benefit of the ADF allocation for both of these objectives is 
that initial toll levels on the project highway will be significantly lower than would be the case if 
only  nonconcessional  financing  were  provided.  By  softening  the  terms  of  the  total  project 
financing, the toll levels can be lowered to socially acceptable levels, and thus the highway can 
be accessible to a much wider section of the population, while maintaining the financial viability 
of VEC and the Project.  
 
28.  Ports Capacity. Hai Phong and Cai Lan are major ports in northern Viet Nam. The Hai 
Phong port has a planned capacity of 6 million tons per year for cargo throughput and 550,000 
twenty-foot equivalent units per year for container throughput. Only midsized vessels can enter 
the port because of its shallow depth. The port mainly serves Southeast Asia. Freight traffic at 
the port is reaching its capacity. The Cai Lan port has a capacity of 15 million tons per year for 
cargo throughput. Large-size vessels can enter the port, and it serves destinations outside 
Southeast Asia. The volume of cargo handled in 2006 was about 1.5 million tons, and the 
volume of containers was about 110,000 twenty-foot equivalent units. Since land transport costs 
were higher because of its geographic disadvantage compared to Hai Phong port, the Cai Lan 
port still has sufficient cargo and container handling capacity. The improved National Road 18 
connects Noi Bai to these ports. Completion of the Bai Chay Bridge on National Road 18 in 
2006 effectively removed the geographical disadvantage of the Cai Lan port. The Project’s 
traffic demand forecast indicates that the growth rate of freight volume will accelerate to an 
annual rate of 4.6–6.1% by 2022. It is expected that these ports will be able to accommodate 
the increased trading demand. 
 
29.  International Trade Zone. The Government’s policy provides incentives to potential 
investors in frontier economic zones, through public sector financing for ground clearance, 
infrastructure development, exemption of land rent, and labor training support. The Lao Cai 
international trade center and Kim Thanh free trade zone are being constructed in the Lao Cai 
international border area. Construction of the Hekou economic zone near the new international 
bridge is also planned on the PRC side. Agroforestry and aquatic products in Viet Nam, and 
electric and mechanical products and chemicals in Yunnan province (PRC) will be, at least 
initially,  significantly  traded  commodities.  Involvement  of  project-affected  households  in  the 
markets in the free trade zone will be an integral part of the income restoration program set out 
in the Project’s REMDP.   
 
30.  Development of Special Industrial Zones. Almost all of the special industrial zones in 
northern Viet Nam are located around Hanoi and along the national roads between Hanoi and 
Hai  Phong.  This  concentration  has  raised  environmental  concerns  and  led  to  unbalanced 
socioeconomic conditions. The Government, therefore, is prioritizing the development of special 
industrial zones west of Hanoi, along the proposed project highway. 
 
31.  Tourism Development. Tourism along the Kunming–Hai Phong Transport Corridor has 
great potential. Sa Pa and Bac Ha in Lao Cai province are famous summer retreats and are 
home to ethnic minority villages that are of interest to tourists. Ha Long Bay, near Hai Phong, is 
registered as natural world heritage site. Yunnan province (PRC) also has several tourist spots, 
including one registered as a world heritage site. However, the two areas are poorly linked, 
especially since the railway in Yunnan province stopped passenger services between Kunming 
and Hekou, on the border with Viet Nam. The Project will strengthen tourism links between the

10 
two countries. Tours highlighting the two countries’ natural, cultural, and ecological features will 
be very attractive to international and domestic tourists. 
 
32.  Mobility of Local Population. Local communities, particularly those living below the 
poverty line, have poor access to economic opportunities, education, and health services. This 
is largely caused by poor road infrastructure, particularly on the right bank of the Red River, 
since the existing roads travel along the left bank and there is very little cross-river access. The 
highway will provide an immediate and significant benefit to communities in this area that have 
never  had  good  road access.  Bus  stops  will  be  installed  in  towns  and  villages  along  the 
highway.  This  will  provide  employment  opportunities  for  the  local  population,  and  improve 
access to socioeconomic services. 
 
33.  Toll Setting and Tolling System. The highway will be tolled as a closed system. The 
toll amount will vary depending on vehicle classification and distance traveled. A card-type toll 
collection system will be introduced. The toll levels will be set from the perspectives of social 
acceptance and VEC’s financial sustainability. The willingness-to-pay survey and the project 
financial study indicated that a level of D800 per km, which is equivalent to $0.05 per km for 
passenger cars, meets the two requirements. However, VEC will make a final determination of 
appropriate toll levels before the highway is opened to public traffic. Periodic review of the toll 
levels will be required to adjust for inflation and unanticipated costs.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Project Benefits 
 
54.  The traffic volume on the existing roads in the project area has been increasing at about 
12% per annum for the last 7 years. In certain sections, the capacity is saturated. If the project 
highway is not constructed, traffic growth will be suppressed and transport costs will increase. 
The congested traffic movements will slow economic growth in the project area. The forecast 
daily traffic volume on the Noi Bai–Viet Tri section, for example, is expected to grow from 
15,300 vehicles in 2012 to 47,600 vehicles in 2022, a 12% average annual growth rate. It will 
then grow more slowly at 5% per annum to reach an average of 77,600 vehicles in 2032 
(Appendix 9). The highway provides additional road capacity of 80,000 vehicles per day for the 
Noi Bai–Yen Bai section, and 20,000 vehicles per day for the Yen Bai–Lao Cai section. 
 
55.  The major project beneficiaries will be (i) highway users, including cargo forwarders, bus 
operators, and tourists; (ii) local residents, who will benefit from improvements in mobility and 
lower prices of commodities and transport services; (iii) local labor involved in the construction 
works and supply of materials during implementation and in operation of the highway; (vi) local 
and international manufacturers and traders, who will be able to establish new businesses and 
increase production capacity; (v) VEC, which will receive toll revenue from highway users; 
(vi) bus operators, who will be able to expand their businesses; and (vii) port authorities in 
northern Viet Nam, whp will see increased cargo volumes. 
 
56.   Economic Benefit. The Project’s economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was estimated 
by comparing the major road networks in northern Viet Nam with and without the Project. 
Without the Project, traffic will use the existing road network, which will be congested and 
expensive to maintain because of rapidly increasing traffic. With the Project, congestion on 
existing roads will be reduced, and traffic on both the project highway and existing roads will 
benefit from faster travel. The project economic costs include (i) capital costs and resettlement 
costs,  excluding  tax  and  price  contingency;  and  (ii)  the  highway’s  O&M  cost.  The  project 
economic benefits are reduced vehicle operating costs and reduced passenger travel times, 
which will be enjoyed both by traffic on the highway and traffic on the existing roads. The Project

B.  Project Impacts 
 
58.  Improved transport infrastructure is critical for sustained rapid economic growth and 
poverty reduction and it can also contribute to regionally balanced and equitable economic 
growth by stimulating the production of goods and increasing trades. Road connectivity under 
the Project will contribute to the ability of the poor to benefit from economic growth in the long 
run. One of the benefits of the Project is that it will reduce travel time between Lao Cai, Hanoi, 
and Hai Phong by up to 50%. The Project will benefit vehicle operators in terms of lower 
transport costs and reduced travel times. The reduced travel time from Hanoi to Lao Cai could 
increase tourism in Sa Pa and surrounding areas. Increased tourism will generate additional 
demand for locally produced goods and services. In addition, lower transport costs and reduced 
travel time will improve access to schools, higher education facilities, and medical facilities in 
the provincial towns.  
 
59.  The highway’s construction will involve a large amount of embankment construction and 
excavation, acquisition of residential and agricultural lands, and resettlement of project-affected 
people,  although  the  final  alignment  has  been  developed  to  ensure  that  environmentally 
sensitive areas are avoided, and impacts on involuntary resettlement are kept to a minimum, as 
required  by  ADB’s  Environment  Policy  (2002)  and  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  (1995). 
Nonetheless, since the social and environmental impacts of the highway’s construction are 
significant, in accordance with ADB’s safeguard policies an EIA and a full REMDP have been 
prepared. Details of the social assessment, including a gender strategy, are shown in the 
Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (Appendix 12).   
 
60.  Environmental Impacts. The alignment of the highway avoids environmentally sensitive 
areas. The project area is mainly agricultural and dominated by rice paddies. People have 
settled  and  cultivated the  area  for  centuries.  The  EIA  identified  no  habitats  of  vulnerable, 
threatened, or endangered flora or fauna within the Project’s impact areas. However, the EIA

18 
identified several major environmental impacts during the construction period, and proposed 
mitigation measures and an EMP. Sand extraction in rivers for road embankment works will be 
done at licensed areas, with care taken to minimize environmental impacts. Surplus excavated 
material generated in the mountainous and hilly sections will be used for embankment of the 
additional two lanes in the Yen Bai-Lao Cai section of the highway. The total volumes of 
excavation and embankment for the Project will be balanced as much as possible to minimize 
the need for soil disposal. The contractors will be required to prepare site-specific EMPs to 
manage environmental impacts at construction camps and construction sites based on the EMP 
of the EIA. Public consultations were carried out in the local language in project-affected areas. 
The  project  design  has  taken  local  concerns  into  consideration  and  provides  several 
underpasses and overpasses to maintain the functions of existing local roads and irrigation 
systems during the highway’s construction and operation. Noise barriers will also be installed in 
environmentally sensitive areas based on noise simulation results. A capacity-building program 
will  be  provided  to  VEC  during  project  implementation  to  strengthen  its  capacity  in 
environmental management and monitoring. 
 
61.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement. The right-of-way of the highway is a minimum of 
50 meters in accordance with the highway standards in Viet Nam. It is estimated that about 
2,000 hectares of land needs to be acquired for the highway construction. Productive land, such 
as rice paddies, fish ponds, vegetable gardens, orchards, and woodland, accounts for 1,800 
hectares (90%) of all affected land. Nonproductive land such as residential land, nonagricultural 
land, and other land (waterways, footpaths, and graveyards) account for 200 hectares (10%). A 
total of 5,458 households (approximately 24,560 persons based on an average household size 
of 4.5) will be adversely affected by losses of assets and sources of livelihood. A total of 3,998 
households will lose more than 10% of their productive land, and the majority of these will lose 
all of their productive land. The socioeconomic surveys also identified 1,083 households that 
were  headed  by  women;  83 households  that  were  headed  by  disabled  persons;  1,210 
households living below the officially set poverty threshold; and 1,586 households that were 
headed by persons within the retirement age bracket of the government. 
 
62.  Ethnic Minority People. The main ethnic minority groups in the project area are Tay, 
Thai, Phu La, Nung, Giay, Moung, and Hamong, and together they represent 18% of the total 
population in the project area. Ethnic minority groups such as Tay, Thai, and Moung who inhabit 
lower mountain areas have long traditions of wet-rice cultivation. They also traditionally interact 
more with the majority Kinh. Although the ethnic minority groups retain their traditional culture, 
religion and social organization, they have adopted mainstream Vietnamese language and 
agricultural practices. Of the 5,458 project-affected households, 136 (approximately 2.4%) are 
from ethnic minority groups. The socioeconomic and inventory-of-losses surveys indicated that 
impacts on the ethnic minority groups and the main ethnic group are the same. However, to 
ensure that ethnic minority groups are not marginalized during the process of implementation of 
resettlement activities, an ethnic minority development plan is incorporated in the resettlement 
plan. 
 
63.  Gender. The resettlement impact on women-headed households is significant since 
women-headed households constitute 20% of the total affected households. In addition, women 
from poor households living below the poverty line will be also affected by resettlement. Poor 
women and women-headed households in the project area face more economic risks (like loss 
of productive assets resulting from land acquisition) and social risks (posed by HIV/AIDS, road 
safety, and possible human trafficking) than males. To address loss of livelihood of poor women 
and women-headed households, the Project includes a livelihood program targeted at women in

accidents increased from 7,100 to 13,200, an increase of more than 20% per annum. In the last 
few years the number has remained a little more stable. In 2004, although the rate was lower, 
with 11,400 fatalities, road accidents still cost the Viet Nam economy $600 million,2 about 1% of

the ratio in developed countries. According to the National Transportation Safety Council of 
Vietnam, 80% of all accidents in 2003 were caused by poor driver behavior, including 33% for 
speeding, 17% for dangerous overtaking, 16% for driver fatigue and 6.5% for driving while 
intoxicated. The condition of roads and vehicles was a minor cause of accidents. About one half 
of road accidents occurred on national roads, particularly those passing through populated 
areas, and one quarter occurred on urban roads. The “urbanization” of road space in Viet Nam 
is a major contributing factor to high accident rates, as many people live within a few meters of 
road sides. Unless urgent action is taken, road traffic fatalities in Viet Nam are predicted to 
continue at current or higher levels. Road safety improvement was clearly recognized as a high 
government priority by the Government of Viet Nam, as reflected in their National Policy on

9.  Development  of  highway  and  expressway  networks  is  one  of  the  most  effective 
approaches to improving road safety and reducing the number of traffic accidents. Accident 
rates on access-controlled highways and expressways are much lower than that on access-free 
general roads. The Project ensures that all important safety measures are in place. Independent 
road safety audits of the project roads will be carried out during final design and construction 
and before the opening of the project highway. Axle-weighing equipment will be installed at the 
Noi Bai and Lao Cai interchanges to control vehicle overloading in the corridor. VEC will 
concentrate on the engineering, the road safety audit, blind-spot improvement, and operational 
issues, while the police will deal with traffic law enforcement.  
 
E.  Cross-Border Operation and Trade 
 
10.  About 1 million tons of cargo is transported annually across the Hekou–Lao Cai border 
crossing points. The daily truck volume observed at the border is approximately 100. Two-
wheeled carts are also broadly used for trading vegetables and fruits. PRC trucks are currently 
allowed to go inside Lao Cai city to transship their cargos to the Vietnamese trucks, and vice-
versa. Transshipment increases transport cost. The governments of Viet Nam and PRC agreed 
to begin implementing the Cross-Border Transport Agreement on the Hekou–Lao Cai border in 
September 2007. This will result in new procedures. The opening of the border crossing to 
international  through  traffic,  which  will  enable  qualified  vehicles  and  operators  to  continue 
through to destination, is one major change in the nature of operations. The formalities and 
procedures will continue in much the same way as before, but will be streamlined to ensure that 
immigration, custom clearance, and quarantine be processed at a single window of the border 
facilities. Consequently, transport costs and travel times will be reduced in both countries, and 
trading volume and traffic volume will increase substantially. 
 
F.  Future Stage of the Noi Bai–Lao Cai Highway 
 
11.  Expressways are high-speed divided highways with access controlled, and should have 
4 or more lanes to allow fast traffic to overtake slow traffic. The two-lane structure for the Yen 
Bai–Lao Cai section of the highway is not an expressway. However, construction of a two-lane 
highway designed to the expressway standard, as a tentative configuration, in medium traffic 
demand areas is a reasonable approach. Compared to the configuration of expressways, a two-
lane highway still has some disadvantages. Overtaking slower traffic is allowed only on limited 
sections. The design capacity of two-lane highways is 20,000 vehicles per day (passenger car 
unit), which is only 25% of four-lane highways. The risk of accidents on two-lane highways is 
much lower than on general roads, as access to the highway is controlled. However, there 
remains a risk of head-on collisions caused by reckless overtaking. Construction of an additional 
two lanes should be considered within 10 years of the project highway’s opening. 
 
12.  The Kim Thanh Bridge in Lao Cai city, which is being constructed across the Red River, 
will be a new international entry point for the Kunming–Hai Phong Transport Corridor. In the 
future, Viet Nam and PRC will establish new cross-border facilities on both sides of the bridge. 
While the Noi Bai–Lao Cai Highway will be constructed up to the Tran Hung Dao Road under 
this Project, it will be connected to the bridge only when traffic demand approaches the highway 
capacity of the Tran Hung Dao Road.

carriageway. The additional two lanes will be completed at a later date when traffic volume 
reaches the highway capacity. The right-of-way for the highway will be acquired based on the

economic development induced by the highway will change land use along its length. This 
approach will ensure that the rapid economic development will not encroach on land required for 
the highway's ultimate configuration. It will also ensure that land acquisition and resettlement 
impacts are planned and implemented in accordance with ADB’s social safeguards policies for 
the ultimate configuration, not just for the first phase. 
 
3.  The census of affected persons and inventory of losses carried out between April and 
June 2007 has estimated that about 2,000 hectare (ha) will be acquired. Productive land, such 
as rice paddies, fish ponds, vegetable gardens, orchards, and woodland, accounts for 89% 
(1,800 ha) of all affected land. A total of 3,998 households will lose more than 10% of their 
productive land, and the majority of these will lose all of their productive land. Nonproductive 
land, such as residential, nonagricultural, and “other land” (e.g. waterways, footpaths, and 
graveyards), accounts for 11%, or about 200 ha. Houses and shops (or kiosks), which will be 
totally affected and will require relocation, account for 1,844 and 11, respectively. Of these, 
around two thirds (1,202 or 65%) will have to acquire new land as the residual land will no 
longer be viable to support rebuilt houses. The remaining 642 households (35%) will be able to 
reconstruct their houses on what remains of their land plots. Secondary structures such as 
kitchens, toilets, porches, and fences were identified. In addition, trees of commercial value will 
also be affected (about 175,000 fruit-bearing trees and 32,000 timber trees) by the Project. The 
Project will also affect public facilities such as electric posts, telephone wires, and communal-
owned irrigation systems.   
 
4.  It  is  estimated  that  5,458  households  (approximately  26,118  persons  based  on  an 
average household size of 4.8) will be adversely affected by loss of assets and sources of 
livelihood. Of these, 97% hold land use rights certificates, are in the process of obtaining land

Appendix 14  61 
use rights certificates, or can claim customary rights over their properties; the rest (148 affected 
households, or 3%) hold lease agreements with the Government.   
 
B.  Legal and Policy Framework  
 
5.  The project resettlement policy and entitlements have been developed from the laws of 
the Government of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, principally the Constitution (1992) that 
confirms the right of citizens to own and protect the ownership of a house; Land Law No. 
13/2003/QH11, providing Viet Nam with a comprehensive land administration law; Decree No. 
197/2004/ND-CP,  on  compensation,  rehabilitation  and  resettlement  in  the  event  of  land 
recovery by the State, as amended by Decree No. 17/2006/ND-CP; Decree No. 188/2004/ND-
CP, specifying the methods for land pricing and land price frameworks in the event of land 
recovery by the State; and ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995) guided by Operations 
Manual on Involuntary Resettlement (2006). Provisions and principles adopted in this Project 
will supplement the provisions of relevant decrees currently in force in Viet Nam wherever a gap 
exists, consistent with Decree No. 131/2006/ND-CP, which provides that in case of “discrepancy 
between any provision in an international treaty on Official Development Assistance (ODA), to 
which the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam is a signatory, and the Vietnamese Law, the provision 
in the international treaty on ODA shall take precedence” (Article 2, Item 5).  
 
C.  Project Entitlements 
 
6.  One of key policy objectives of the Project is to replace and compensate lost assets. All 
compensation is based on the principle of replacement cost. Compensation and provision of 
assistance  will  be  provided  and  income  restoration  programs  will  be  put  in  place  prior  to 
displacement of affected households from their houses, land, and assets, such that they will be 
at least as well off as they would have been in the absence of the Project, and the poorest 
affected households and vulnerable groups, including affected persons from ethnic minorities, 
are assisted to help improve their socioeconomic status. The project entitlements are shown in 
Table A14.1 below. 
 
7.  The type and number of affected persons and the entitlements will be added to the 
updated  REMDP,  as  needed,  to  cover  other  eligible  persons  (for  example,  tenants  losing 
government or private housing, non-titled users on government land, registered establishments 
that will be required to relocate) and impacts identified during the detailed measurement survey. 
They will be eligible for compensation and assistance provided that they meet the established 
cutoff date.  
 
D.  Ethnicity, Vulnerability, and Gender Issues 
 
8.  The  census  has  identified  136  households  (2.44%  of  the  total  number  of  affected 
households) belonging to six ethnic minority groups that will be affected by the Project—namely, 
the  Tay,  Dao,  Giay,  Thai,  Muong,  and  Mong.  Likewise,  the  census  has  identified  1,083 
households (19.84%) headed by women, 83 households (1.52%) headed by disabled persons 
(all males), 1,210 households (22.17%) living below the officially set poverty threshold, and 
1,586  households  (29.06%)  headed  by  persons  within  the  retirement  age  bracket  of  the 
Government (i.e., 55 or older for women, and 60 or older for men). Particular attention has been 
given to the specific needs and concerns of ethnic minorities and other vulnerable groups such 
as the landless, poor, and households headed by women, disabled, elderly, or children without 
means of support. Ethnic minority and gender strategies are included in the REMDP. Such 
strategies include active participation of women and ethnic minorities from the consultation

stage to the monitoring stage; representation of women and ethnic minorities in resettlement 
committees;  and  capacity-building  targeting  women  and  ethnic  minorities.  To  ensure  the 
effective implementation of the ethnic minority development plan and gender strategies, the 
project supervision consultant (PSC) will employ specialists in social development, gender, and 
ethnic minority issues. Monitoring indicators broken down by gender and ethnic minority will be 
developed, and the external monitoring agency will include a female staff member.

E.  Participation and Grievance Redress 
 
9.  Consultations, public meetings, and village discussions with affected households and 
local officials were carried out during the resettlement planning process. These activities will 
continue  during  updating  and  implementation  and  will  follow  the  Project’s  participatory 
approach. A grievance mechanism has been designed to ensure that affected households’ 
concerns and grievances are addressed and resolved in a timely and satisfactory manner.  
Affected households will be made fully aware of their rights verbally and in writing during 
consultation, survey, and at the time of compensation. 
 
F.  Income Restoration and Relocation Strategies 
 
10.  The  inventory  of  losses  has  identified  3,998  affected  households  that  stand  to  be 
severely affected by the loss of 10% or more of their productive assets, most of which are land-
based (i.e., rice paddies, gardens for growing vegetables and perennials, fish or shrimp ponds, 
or woodlands).  Wherever feasible, VEC will allow the cultivation of annual crops (e.g., rice and 
low-lying crops) on land inside the right-of-way that is not required during the first phase of the 
highway  project.  This  will  be  carried  out  as  a  collective  endeavor  of  severely  affected 
households  in  a  particular  village  or  commune  under  the  close  supervision  of  the  local 
authorities, VEC, and the consultants, in line with the Project's income restoration program. The 
temporary permit to utilize said land is given on the condition, and with clear understanding by 
all concerned, that in the event that such land is required for improving or carrying out the 
second phase of the highway project, the possession of the same will be relinquished to VEC at 
no cost to the government.   
 
11.  During the TA loan stage, a local organization that has a track record in community-
based socioeconomic work will be contracted to design, pilot, and commence implementation of 
a responsive income restoration program in each commune with the full participation of the 
affected  households  and  local  authorities,  especially  the  compensation,  assistance,  and 
resettlement boards (CARBs) in the project provinces and in the project districts.1 The progress 
(cid:31)(cid:31)F
of the income restoration program will be monitored regularly and will be evaluated every 6 
months to ensure attainment of objectives. Modifications in the program and additional cash and 
material assistance to the participating affected households will be provided as and when 
necessary.  Subject  to  satisfactory  performance,  the  PSC  can  subcontract  the  same  local 
organization to continue to implement the income restoration program until its completion in 
2010. 
 
12.  The income restoration organization will also carry out a detailed assessment of present 
skills vis-à-vis the labor requirements in industrial zones and in neighboring places that have 
factories in line with the design and implementation of training programs and/or vocational 
courses. Additionally, short-term employment at the worksite (as laborers) or in the offices of the 
civil works contractor and supervision consultants will be made available to members of the 
affected households, especially the severely affected, as practicable. 
 
13.  Of the 1,844 affected households who stand to lose entire houses and therefore must 
relocate, 1,169 households will have to acquire new land on which to rebuild their homes. Initial 
meetings with the local authorities show the availability or nonavailability of replacement land 
per commune. During REMDP updating, the final location of sites (individual or small group 
relocation  sites)  will  be  determined  in  close  coordination  with  the  local  authorities  and  in

64  Appendix 14 
consultation  with  affected  households  to  ensure  that  the  social  and  economic  implications 
caused by relocation will be avoided or at least minimized. Affected households will not be 
displaced until a suitable relocation site is provided to them.    
 
G.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  VEC will have overall responsibility for all land acquisition and resettlement activities.  
The technical department of the VEC will create a social and resettlement unit (SRU) to provide 
overall  guidance  and  coordinate  closely  with  MOT  and  local  authorities.  The  SRU  will  be 
headed by a senior social development and resettlement officer and six social development and 
resettlement staff members. For this Project, four staff members of the SRU will be full-time 
members of the project management team (PMT) and will be assigned on a full-time basis to 
each project field office. The four SRU staff members will represent the PMT in the provincial 
CARBs and will act as conduit between MOT, the local governments, VEC, and the project 
consultants. 
 
15.  The provincial and district CARBs, under the guidance of VEC, will carry out updating 
and implementation of resettlement within their administrative jurisdictions in accordance with 
the approved and updated REMDP. Each CARB will be headed by the vice chairman of the 
provincial  or  district  people’s  committee  and  will  include  members  from  departments 
concerned—including the departments of finance, national resource and environment, transport, 
and agriculture—and representatives from local organizations and project affected persons. 
 
16.  The consultants engaged under the TA loan will continue to assist the SRU staff and the 
CARBs during REMDP updating and implementation to ensure social safeguards compliance. 
These consultants will continue to provide training and capacity-building interventions on a full-
time  basis.  The  social  development  and  resettlement  team  will  be  composed  of:  one 
international  resettlement  specialist;  one  international  social  development  specialist;  one 
national resettlement specialist; one national ethnic minority specialist; one national gender 
specialist; a national training program expert; and five provincial coordinators and assistants. In 
addition,  the  consultants  under  the  TA  loan will  subcontract  a qualified  local  development 
organization to design and implement income restoration programs. 
 
H.  Monitoring, REMDP Budget and Implementation Schedule 
 
17.  The  contract  of  the  consultants  engaged  under  the  TA  loan  will  be  completed  in 
September 2008; hence, implementation of updated REMDPs, including income restoration 
programs, will be handed over to the PSC. At least 1 month prior to demobilization of the 
consultants engaged under the TA loan, the PSC will mobilize a similar social development and 
resettlement team with the same tasks to ensure continuous assistance to the PMT and CARBs 
during  implementation  of  the  updated  REMDPs,  and  to  act  on  issues  and  unforeseen 
resettlement impacts. Subject to satisfactory performance, the PSC can subcontract the same 
local  organization  engaged  by  the  consultants  under  the  TA  loan  to  continue  with  the 
implementation of income restoration programs. 
 
18.  VEC will have overall responsibility for internal monitoring of resettlement activities. 
Progress reports will be submitted to ADB on a quarterly basis. An external monitoring agency 
will be mobilized 1 month following the start of updating of the district-level REMDPs. The 
external monitoring agency will be required to submit an inception report 1 month following its 
mobilization and quarterly reports on the progress of updating of the district-level REMDPs  and 
implementation,  and  make  recommendations  regarding  the  issues  identified.  The  external

Appendix 14  65 
monitoring agency will likewise conduct a post-resettlement implementation evaluation study 6–
12 months following completion of resettlement activities. 
 
19.  The total cost for resettlement is estimated at $100 million. This includes compensation 
and  allowances,  development  of  replacement  plots  for  relocating  households,  design  and 
implementation of livelihood programs, operational and administration expenses, and internal 
and external monitoring. Additionally, $15 million contingency for resettlement cost is included in 
the total project cost. VEC will ensure the timely provision of counterpart funds for resettlement 
to meet any unforeseen obligations in excess of the resettlement budget estimates.  
 
20.  Following detailed highway design, REMDP updating will be carried out by the district 
people’s committees (DPCs) in the project area. As soon as an updated REMDP is completed 
by a DPC, VEC will submit it to ADB for review and approval. All resettlement activities will be 
coordinated  with  the  civil  works  schedule.  Land  acquisition  and  relocation  of  affected 
households in a given district can commence only once ADB has reviewed and approved the 
updated REMDP for that district. Each civil works contract package covers highway construction 
in more than one district. VEC will issue a notice to proceed to the civil works contractors for the 
particular highway section in a district where (i) compensation payment and relocation to new 
sites have been satisfactorily completed, (ii) rehabilitation assistance is in place, and (iii) the 
particular length required for civil works is free of all encumbrances. The contractors do not 
need to delay commencement of the civil works until the land acquisition and resettlement 
activities have been completed for the entire sections covered by their contracts.

I.  Disclosure of REMDP 
 
22.  Key information in the draft REMDP has been disclosed to the affected households from 
24–26 July 2007 through the distribution of public information booklets translated into the local 
language. Full and summary versions of the REMDP, translated into the local language, have 
been placed in provincial, district, and commune offices. Likewise, the draft REMDP has been 
uploaded onto the ADB website. Following approval of the draft REMDP by VEC and ADB, the 
updated REMDP will again be disclosed to the affected households and uploaded onto the ADB 
website. The updated district-level REMDPs (draft and approved) will likewise be disclosed to 
the affected households and uploaded onto the ADB website. Social monitoring reports will be 
made available to the affected households and will be submitted to ADB for web posting.
